Column Comment.0: SUPPORT FACILITY SUBTYPE: The type of support facility that is described by thisrow of data. These values are managed by check constraint, and may only be thename of a valid sub type of support facility.
Column Comment.1: RIG IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier assigned to the rig. Rigs may be drilling rigs orother kinds of service rigs assigned to a well site.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: BOILER MANUFACTURER: Unvalidated column for the manufacturer information forthe boiler. For validated manufacturer information, go to the EQUIPMENT tables.
Column Comment.4: BOILDER POWER: Power rating for the boiler.
Column Comment.6: CHOKE MANIFOLD PRESSURE: A set of high-pressure valves and associatedpiping that usually includes at least two adjustable chokes, arranged such that oneadjustable choke may be isolated and taken out of service for repair andrefurbishment while well flow is directed through the other one. (SchlumbergerOilfield Glossary).
Column Comment.8: CHOKE MANIFOLD SIZE: A set of high-pressure valves and associated piping thatusually includes at least two adjustable chokes, arranged such that one adjustablechoke may be isolated and taken out of service for repair and refurbishment whilewell flow is directed through the other one. (Schlumerger Oilfield Glossary)
Column Comment.10: CLEAR WORKING HEIGHT: the amount of clear working height space on the rig.
Column Comment.12: COMMISSION DATE: The date that the rig was put into commission.
Column Comment.13: DECOMMISSION DATE: The date that the rig was decommissioned.
Column Comment.14: DESANDER TYPE:A hydrocyclone device that removes large drill solids from thewhole mud system. The desander should be located downstream of the shaleshakers and degassers, but before the desilters or mud cleaners. A volume of mud ispumped into the wide upper section of the hydrocylone at an angle roughly tangent toits circumference. As the mud flows around and gradually down the inside of thecone shape, solids are separated from the liquid by centrifugal forces. The solidscontinue around and down until they exit the bottom of the hydrocyclone (along withsmall amounts of liquid) and are discarded. The cleaner and lighter density liquidmud travels up through a vortex in the center of the hydrocyclone, exits throughpiping at the top of the hydrocyclone and is then routed to the mud tanks and the nextmud-cleaning device, usually a desilter. Various size desander and desilter cones arefunctionally identical, with the size of the cone determining the size of particles thedevice removes from the mud system. (Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary).
Column Comment.15: DESILTER TYPE: A hydrocyclone much like a desander except that its designincorporates a greater number of smaller cones. As with the desander, its purpose isto remove unwanted solids from the mud system. The smaller cones allow thedesilter to efficiently remove smaller diameter drill solids than a desander does. Forthat reason, the desilter is located downstream from the desander in the surface mudsystem. (Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary).
Column Comment.16: DRAWWORKS TYPE: The machine on the rig consisting of a large-diameter steelspool, brakes, a power source and assorted auxiliary devices. The primary function ofthe drawworks is to reel out and reel in the drilling line, a large diameter wire rope, inacontrolled fashion. The drilling line is reeled over the crown block and traveling blockto gain mechanical advantage in a "block and tackle" or "pulley" fashion. This reelingout and in of the drilling line causes the traveling block, and whatever may behanging underneath it, to be lowered into or raised out of the wellbore. The reelingout of the drilling line is powered by gravity and reeling in by an electric motor ordiesel engine.(Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary). A link to the specific piece ofequipment that has been used may be captured in the table SF EQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.17: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.18: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.19: HOOKBLOCK RATING: The rating for the hookblock, as the amount of force it israted for.
Column Comment.21: HOOK or HOOKBLOCK TYPE: The high-capacity J-shaped equipment used to hangvarious other equipment, particularly the swivel and kelly, the elevator bails ortopdrive units. The hook is attached to the bottom of the traveling block and providesa way to pick up heavy loads with the traveling block. The hook is either locked (thenormal condition) or free to rotate, so that it may be mated or decoupled with itemspositioned around the rig floor, not limited to a single direction. (Schlumberger OilfieldGlossary)
Column Comment.22: HOOK LOAD CAPACITY: The maximum hook load rated for this rig. Hook load is thetotal force pulling down on the hook. This total force includes the weight of thedrillstring in air, the drill collars and any ancillary equipment, reduced by any forcethat tends to reduce that weight. Some forces that might reduce the weight includefriction along the wellbore wall (especially in deviated wells) and, importantly, buoyantforces on the drillstring caused by its immersion in drilling fluid. If the BOPs areclosed, any pressure in the wellbore acting on the cross-sectional area of thedrillstring in the BOPs will also exert an upward force. (Schlumberger OilfieldGlossary)
Column Comment.24: KELLY BUSHING TO GROUND DISTANCE: the distance from the kelly bushing tothe ground on the rig.
Column Comment.26: MAST HEIGHT: The height of the mast.
Column Comment.28: MAST TYPE: The structure used to support the crown blocks and the drillstring.Masts are usually rectangular or trapezoidal in shape and offer a very good stiffness,important to land rigs whose mast is laid down when the rig is moved. They sufferfrom being heavier than conventional derricks and consequently are not usuallyfound in offshore environments, where weight is more of a concern than in landoperations. (Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary). In order to capture a relationship to aspecific piece of equipment or the manufacturer of the equipment,please use SFEQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.29: MAXIMUM DEPTH: The maximum depth that the rig is able to drill to.
Column Comment.31: MUD TANK COUNT: The number of mud tanks for the rig.
Column Comment.32: MUD TANK SIZE: The size of the mud tanks on the rig.
Column Comment.34: OPERATOR BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for thebusiness associate who operates the rig.
Column Comment.35: OWNER BUSINESS ASSOCIATE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the businessassociate who owns the rig. Note that partner shares can be handled through theINTEREST SET module, via the foreign key in SF COMPONENT.
Column Comment.36: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.37: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.38: RIG CATEGORY: The category of the rig, describing its basic purpose. Typicalexamples include drilling rig, service rig, wireline rig, workover rig, rathole rig etc.
Column Comment.39: RIG CLASS: Indicates the class of rig, such as single, super single, double, triple.
Column Comment.40: RIG CODE: This reference table defines the unique codes assigned to each rig orinstallation. For example, the code "GA" may be assigned to the drilling rig GlomarArctic III.
Column Comment.41: RIG NAME: Full name of the rig. Usually denormalized from the table SF ALIAS,based on the PREFERRED IND flag.
Column Comment.42: RIG TYPE: A reference table describing the type of rig installation. For example land,barge, submersible, platform, jackup, drillship, semisub or artificial island.
Column Comment.43: ROTARY TABLE CAPACITY: the carrying capacity of the rotary table, often in tons.
Column Comment.45: ROTARY TABLE SIZE: The revolving or spinning section of the drillfloor thatprovides power to turn the drillstring in a clockwise direction (as viewed from above).The rotary motion and power are transmitted through the kelly bushing and the kellyto the drillstring. When the drillstring is rotating, the drilling crew commonly describesthe operation as simply, "rotating to the right," "turning to the right," or, "rotating onbottom." Almost all rigs today have a rotary table, either as primary or backup systemfor rotating the drillstring. Topdrive technology, which allows continuous rotation ofthe drillstring, has replaced the rotary table in certain operations. A few rigs are beingbuilt today with topdrive systems only, and lack the traditional kelly system.(Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary)
Column Comment.47: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.48: SUBSTRUCTURE: Foundation on which the derrick and engines sit. Contains spacefor storage and well control equipment. (http://www.oilonline.com/info/glossary.asp).For details about specific equipment used or manufacturers, please use the SFEQUIPMENTtable.
Column Comment.49: SUBSTRUCTURE CASING CAPACITY: The maximum capacity of the substructureto hold casings removed from the well bore, including those that are hung from theoverhead equjpment.
Column Comment.51: SUSTRUCTURE SET BACK CAPACITY: The amount of force the substructure canhandle as wieght on the derrick and rack in addition to the normal rig equipment.
Column Comment.53: SWIVEL RATING: The rating for the swivel, usually the weight it is able to hold. Theswivel is a rotary device hanging from the hook and the travellling block. Its functionis to allow the drill stem to rotate freely from the apparatus.
Column Comment.54: SWIVEL RATING ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: The units of measure in whichthe swivel rating was originally received.
Column Comment.55: SWIVEL TYPE: A mechanical device that must simultaneously suspend the weight ofthe drillstring, provide for rotation of the drillstring beneath it while keeping the upperportion stationary, and permit high-volume flow of high-pressure drilling mud from thefixed portion to the rotating portion without leaking. (Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary)
Column Comment.56: TOP DRIVE MODEL: unvalidated information about the make and model of the topdrive. In order to validate this information, please use SF EQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.57: TOP DRIVE RATING: the rating for the top drive. The top drive is used to rotate thedrill stem, and may be used in place of the rotary table. The top drive may include theswivel, elevator, tongs and hook.
Column Comment.58: TOP DRIVE RATING ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: The units of measure inwhich the top drive rating was originally received.
Column Comment.59: WATER DEPTH CAPACITY: Depth of the water that the rig can operate in.
Column Comment.60: WATER DEPTH DATUM: Identifies the point near or on the rig from where the waterdepths are to be measured.
Column Comment.61: WATER DEPTH OUOM: Water depth original unit of measure.
Column Comment.62: WORKING PRESSURE: The working pressure for the rig.
Column Comment.64: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.65: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.66: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.67: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.68: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.69: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.70: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
